revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{Taxobox | image = Bol.poro.jpg | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Boletales]] | familia = [[Boletaceae]] | genus = ''[[Boletus]]'' | species = '''''B. porosporus''''' | binomial = ''Boletus porosporus'' | binomial_authority = Imler ex Bon & G. Moreno (1977) | synonyms =
'''''Xerocomus porosporus'''''
Imler (1958)
}} {{mycomorphbox | name = Boletus porosporus | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=pores | stipeCharacter=bare | sporePrintColor=olive-brown | howEdible= edible }} '''''Boletus porosporus''''' is a small wild mushroom in the [[Boletaceae]] family. These mushrooms have tubes and pores instead of gills beneath their [[Pileus (mycology)|caps]]. It is commonly known as the '''sepia bolete'''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5641~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp|title=Rogers Mushrooms | Mushroom Pictures & Mushroom Reference|accessdate=2009-03-23|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101025323/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5641~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp|archivedate=2011-01-01}} ==Taxonomy== This species was previously known as ''Xerocomus porosporus''; the genus ''Xerocomus'' is now reduced to synonymy with ''Boletus''. ==Description== When fully expanded, the [[Pileus (mycology)|caps]] are up to {{convert|8|cm|in}} in diameter, and are soon cracked or [https://web.archive.org/web/20110615141333/http://www.bioimages.org.uk/html/p2/p29169.php fissured.] Varying in colour from putty beige to dull brown,{{Cite book| vauthors = Courtecuisse R, Duhem B | year = 1995 | title = Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and Europe (British version) | publisher = Harper Collins | isbn = 0-00-220025-2}} or olivaceous.{{Cite book| author = Bon M | year = 1987 | title = The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe | publisher = Hodder and Stoughton | isbn = 0-340-39935-X}} The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is usually with very little red, and is olivaceous, more yellow at the apex, and bruises brown. The flesh is pale lemon yellow or buff in the cap, and chrome yellow in the stem apex. It darkens to dark brick or [[wine (color)|vinaceous]] towards the base. The tubes are {{convert|13|to|20|cm|in}} long, initially lemon yellow, later olivaceous, and they bruise bluish. The pores are narrow, 0.2–0.5 mm in diameter, angular, lemon yellow, and darken later. They also bruise blue. The spores give an olive-brown [[spore print]].{{Cite book| author = Phillips R | year = 2006 | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 0-330-44237-6}} At microscopic level this bolete has truncate (chopped off) spores;{{Cite book |author=Arora D |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Demystified |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} the spore dimensions are 13–15 by 4–5 [[micrometre|µm]].{{Cite book|vauthors=Ellis JB, Ellis MB |title=Fungi without Gills (Hymenomycetes and Gasteromycetes): an Identification Handbook |publisher=Chapman and Hall |location=London |year=1990 |page=45 |isbn=0-412-36970-2}} ==Distribution and habitat== ''B. porosporus'' appears occasionally in the autumn, and grows singly or in small groups in mixed [[deciduous]] woods, particularly with [[oak]], [[Carpinus|hornbeams]], and [[beech]]. This species is widespread in northern [[temperate zones]], but somewhat rare in Europe.{{Cite journal|doi=10.1017/S0953756203007901 |vauthors=Peintner U, Ladurner H, Simonini G|title=''Xerocomus cisalpinus'' sp. nov., and the delimitation of species in the''X. chrysenteron'' complex based on morphology and rDNA-LSU sequences|journal=Mycological Research |volume=107 |issue=Pt 6 |pages=659–79|year=2003|pmid=12951793}} ==Edibility== ''B. porosporus'' is edible but of little culinary value, being bland, and mushy when cooked. ==See also== [[List of Boletus species|List of ''Boletus'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q2501490}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boletus Porosporus}} [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Boletus|porosporus]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1958]]
